p:
An H7N7 equine IAV was first isolated during a 1956 epizootic
50 but is now likely extinct;
51 an H3N8 equine IAV, detected in the early 1960s
52 still circulates enzootically to cause significant disease and economic burden.
53 Equine H3N8 viruses can infect humans experimentally,
54 , and it has been noted by several groups that human birth cohorts from the late 19th century, particularly those born before about 1893, demonstrated serologic reactivity with equine H3N8 viruses many decades later.
55
